content.text: Do **not** remove the spring from the clamp. Use the metre rule to measure the length \(l_0\) of the coiled part of the spring
Record \(l_0\), in Table 1.1 at load \(L = 0.0 \text{N}\)
• On Fig. 1.1, show clearly the length \(l_0\)
Place a load \(L = 1.0 \text{N}\) on the spring. Record, in Table 1.1, the length \(l\) of the coiled part of the spring
• Repeat this procedure using loads \(L = 2.0 \text{N}\), \(3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\) and \(5.0 \text{N}\)
Describe **one** precaution that you took in order to obtain reliable readings
Plot a graph of \(l / \text{mm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(L / \text{N}\) (\(x\)-axis)
A student suggests that the length \(l\) of the spring is directly proportional to the load \(L\)
State whether your readings support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the graph line
Use your results to predict the load \(L\) that would give a length \(l\) twice the value of \(l_0\)
Show clearly how you obtained your answer
In this experiment, you will investigate the stretching of a spring
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Use the thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
• Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker
• Measure the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water in the beaker. Record this temperature in Table 2.1 at time \(t = 0s\)
• Immediately start the stopclock
• After 180 s, measure the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer. Record the time and temperature in the table
• After a total of 360 s, measure the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer. Record the time and temperature in the table
• Calculate the temperature fall \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) during the first 180 s
\(\Delta \theta_{1} =\)
• Calculate the temperature fall \(\Delta \theta_{2}\) during the next 180 s
\(\Delta \theta_{2} =\)
Suggest why \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) is different from \(\Delta \theta_{2}\)
Suggest two changes that you could make to the procedure to obtain a larger difference between the values of \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) and \(\Delta \theta_{2}\)
Fig. 2.1 shows a measuring cylinder. **A**, **B**, **C** and **D** are four possible lines of sight that could be used to read the volume of the water
Give **two** reasons why **B** should be used to obtain the most accurate reading
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water
Draw a line \(\mathbf{FE}\), to the left of the normal and at an angle of incidence \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper. Draw the outline of the block **ABCD**
• Remove the block and draw a normal **NL** at the centre of side **AB**. Label the point **E** where the normal crosses **AB**. Label the point **M** where the normal crosses **CD**
Measure and record the length \(x\) between points \(\mathbf{M}\) and \(\mathbf{K}\)
x =
Measure and record the angle \(\alpha\) between the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the line \(\mathbf{KL}\)
\(\alpha =\)
Repeat steps (a) and (b) with the angle of incidence \(i = 50^{\circ}\)
\(\alpha =\)
x =
A student suggests that the angle \(\alpha\) should always be equal to the angle of incidence \(i\)
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the readings
statement
justification
Suggest one precaution that you should take with this experiment to obtain reliable results
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light passing through a transparent block
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance
A student is investigating whether the resistance of a wire depends on the material from which the wire is made
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
The following apparatus is available to the student:
ammeter
voltmeter
power supply (0–3 V)
micrometer screw gauge
variable resistor
switch
connecting leads
wires made of different materials
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the resistance of a wire depends on the material from which the wire is made. You are **not** required to carry out this investigation
You should:
* draw a diagram of the circuit you would use to determine the resistance of each wire
* explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements you would take
* state the key variables that you would control
* draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
